summary: A detailed instructional video lesson on the respiratory system focusing on the Mouth, Pharynx, and Larynx.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The lesson is titled "Lesson 2: Mouth, Pharynx and Larynx" and is part of an 11th-grade biology course taught by Mr. DeKezel. The background is a blue gradient with white text, and a list of key points is displayed on the right side of the screen, including the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. The instructor, wearing a red shirt, is seated in a room with a neutral-colored wall and a framed picture in the background. The video begins with a static image of the lesson title and key points, with a cursor icon moving across the screen, indicating the start of the lesson. The atmosphere is educational and focused, with the instructor likely preparing to explain the topics listed.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker greeting a biology class and introducing lesson two on the "respiratory system," specifying the "mouth, pharynx, and larynx." He notes they've discussed these topics in the digestive system unit and will approach them in a different context. He then highlights key points, including "mouth, cleft palate, pharynx and larynx" and calls them "self-explanatory." He says they will "jump right in" and talk about it in a "breathing context," then mentions "nose to mouth."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a red shirt, standing in front of a blue background with a slide titled "Nose to Mouth." The slide explains the connection between the nose and mouth through the nasopharynx and oropharynx at the back of the throat. It includes a list of key points: Mouth, Cleft Palate, Pharynx, and Larynx. Additionally, there are two YouTube links provided for further resources. The man appears to be teaching a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The slide also displays the logo of "11 Biology Mr. DeKezel," indicating the educational context of the video. The man seems to be explaining the content on the slide, likely addressing the audience directly. The environment suggests an educational setting, possibly a classroom or a virtual learning platform. The video maintains a consistent visual theme throughout, with no significant changes in the background or the man's position.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining the connection between the nose and mouth. He notes that they are linked by "the nasopharynx and oropharynx" at the back of the throat, allowing one to "breathe through your nose or your mouth" to the same place, establishing a connection. He speaks in an informative, conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing glasses and a red shirt, standing in front of a blue background with a slide titled "Nose to Mouth." The slide explains the connection between the nose and mouth through the nasopharynx and oropharynx at the back of the throat. It includes a list of key points: Mouth, Cleft Palate, Pharynx, and Larynx. Additionally, there are two YouTube video links labeled "Chain" and "Nose Speakers." The man appears to be teaching a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx, as indicated by the text at the bottom of the slide. The classroom setting is simple, with a whiteboard and a few decorations visible in the background. The man gestures with his hands, likely emphasizing points from the slide, and maintains a focused expression throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker describing how a chain can be put through the nose and pulled out of the mouth, suggesting it shows the connection between the two. He then mentions using headphones to create a speaker, implying it utilizes this connection. He suggests people check out related videos. The speaker describes how they supposedly prove "that your nose and your mouth are connected" and that "they both lead to the same place which is your throat."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a red shirt seated in front of a blue background, delivering a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The slide displayed behind him highlights key points such as the mouth's role in eating, drinking, and speaking, and the concept of mouth breathing as a response to nasal obstruction. The slide also lists the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx as important components of the respiratory system. The man appears to be explaining these concepts, with his facial expressions and gestures indicating engagement with the material. The setting is a classroom or educational environment, with a logo and the name "Mr. DeKezel" visible on the slide, suggesting he is the instructor. The video maintains a consistent focus on the educational content, with no significant changes in the scene or background throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining the role of the mouth in various functions like eating, drinking, and speaking, characterizing the latter as a respiratory system role. He then introduces the concept of mouth breathing as an alternative to nasal breathing in cases of obstruction. His speaking tone is informative and clear.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing a red shirt, seated in front of a blue background with a slide titled "Mouth." The slide explains the mouth's role in eating, drinking, and speaking, and defines mouth breathing as breathing through the mouth when the nose is obstructed. The slide also lists key points: Mouth, Cleft Palate, Pharynx, and Larynx. The person appears to be teaching a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The classroom setting includes a wall with framed pictures and a logo with the letter "M" and the text "11 Biology Mr. DeKezel." The video maintains a consistent educational atmosphere throughout, with the presenter likely elaborating on the slide's content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the benefits of breathing through the nose rather than the mouth, especially for filtering and warming air before it enters the lungs. The speaker explains that mouth breathing can be useful during physical activity or when there's a blockage, but is not recommended for regular life, particularly in cold climates.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The presenter, wearing a red shirt, stands in front of a blue background with a diagram of the human mouth and throat. The lesson begins with a slide titled "Cleft Palate," explaining its formation and effects on voice, alongside a key points list and a logo for "11 Biology Mr. DeKezel." The presenter gestures towards the slide as the cursor highlights the text. The video then transitions to a slide about the "Pharynx," detailing its role in connecting the oral and nasal cavities, its function in the digestive and respiratory systems, and its role in filtering, warming, and moistening air. The presenter continues to explain the content, with the cursor pointing to the text. The background remains consistent throughout, with the presenter's gestures and the cursor's movements guiding the viewer through the lesson.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker describing a cleft palate and its impact on voice, mentioning it is easily repaired with surgery. The speaker then defines the pharynx and its role in the digestive and respiratory systems as well as air filtration.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The presenter, wearing a red shirt, is seated in a room with a blue wall and a framed picture in the background. The lesson begins with a slide titled "Pharynx," which explains that the human pharynx is divided into three sections: nasopharynx, oropharynx, and laryngopharynx. The slide also highlights the function of the pharynx, which is to connect the nose and mouth to the lower respiratory system. The key points of the lesson are listed on the right side of the slide, including the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. The lesson is part of an 11th-grade biology class taught by Mr. DeKezel. The video then transitions to a detailed anatomical diagram of the pharynx, nasal cavity, oral cavity, tongue, jaw, epiglottis, larynx, and esophagus, with labels pointing to each part. The presenter continues to explain the diagram, pointing out the larynx opening into the pharynx. The lesson is part of a series on the respiratory system, as indicated by the text at the bottom of the screen. The video maintains a consistent educational atmosphere throughout, with the presenter actively engaging with the material and the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the pharynx, dividing it into sections like the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and laryngopharynx, mentioning its function of connecting the nose and mouth to the lower respiratory system and enabling eating and breathing at the same time. He describes the different types of pharynx and references a picture showing the nasopharynx, oropharynx, laryngopharynx, larynx, and trachea, also explaining the role of the epiglottis in blocking the windpipe during eating. His tone is informative and educational throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing a red shirt, seated in front of a background that includes a wall with framed pictures and a door. The individual appears to be delivering an educational presentation on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the epiglottis. The presentation includes a slide with text explaining the function and significance of the epiglottis, as well as the potential complications of epiglottitis. The slide also lists key points related to the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. Additionally, there are two YouTube video links provided for further reference. The presenter, identified as Mr. DeKezel, is associated with an 11 Biology class, as indicated by the logo and text on the slide. Throughout the video, the presenter's facial expressions and gestures suggest an engaging and informative delivery of the lesson. The overall atmosphere is educational and focused on conveying information about the respiratory system.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker discussing the epiglottis, explaining its function in preventing food from entering the windpipe and its role in breathing and speaking. He notes the difficulty of speaking and eating simultaneously due to the epiglottis needing to open and close at the same time. His tone is informative and somewhat educational.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing a red shirt, seated in front of a blue background with a whiteboard displaying information about the epiglottis. The whiteboard includes text explaining the function of the epiglottis, its inflammation (epiglottitis), and the potential consequences of a swollen epiglottis. Additionally, there are two YouTube links provided for further information. On the right side of the screen, a list of key points related to the respiratory system is visible, including the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. The video is part of a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx, as indicated by the text at the bottom of the screen. The person appears to be explaining the content on the whiteboard, with their hand gestures and facial expressions suggesting an engaging and informative presentation. The background includes a wall with framed pictures and a door, adding a personal touch to the educational setting. The video maintains a consistent visual theme throughout, with no significant changes in the environment or the person's actions.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker describing "epiglottitis" as an inflammation that can cause breathing difficulties. He suggests watching videos to understand the epiglottis's function, referring to a "digestion unit." The clip concludes with a faint, unidentifiable sound effect.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a red shirt, seated in a room with a blue wall and framed pictures, delivering a lesson on the respiratory system. The lesson focuses on the larynx, commonly known as the voice box, which is located in the top of the neck and plays a crucial role in breathing, sound production, and protecting the trachea. The man gestures with his hands to emphasize his points, and the slide on the screen highlights key points such as the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. The slide also explains that the larynx houses the vocal cords and manipulates pitch and volume, which is essential for phonation. The lesson is part of an 11th-grade biology course taught by Mr. DeKezel, as indicated by the text on the slide. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with the man's gestures and the slide's content providing a clear and educational overview of the larynx's functions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the larynx as the voice box, located in the neck, mentioning the Adam's apple and cartilage. He indicates its involvement in breathing, sound production, and protection of the trachea, further elaborating on its role in housing the vocal cords and manipulating pitch and volume for phonation.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a lesson on the respiratory system, specifically focusing on the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The presenter, wearing a red shirt, is seated in a room with a blue wall and framed pictures in the background. The lesson begins with a slide titled "Larynx," explaining that the larynx, commonly known as the voice box, is an organ in the top of the neck involved in breathing, producing sound, and protecting the trachea. It houses the vocal cords and manipulates pitch and volume, essential for phonation. The slide also lists key points: Mouth, Cleft Palate, Pharynx, and Larynx, with the lesson being part of an 11th-grade biology class taught by Mr. DeKezel. The video then transitions to a close-up image of the larynx, showing its internal structure. Following this, the lesson shifts to "Voice Up and Down," discussing the effects of breathing different gases like helium, sulfur hexafluoride, and xenon, with corresponding YouTube links provided for further explanation. Throughout the video, the presenter appears engaged, using hand gestures to emphasize points, and the classroom setting remains consistent, creating an educational atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing how to manipulate voice pitch and volume, associating phonation with speaking. He mentions the use of microphones and helium to alter voice and shows a picture of the larynx, describing the cartilage protecting the vocal cords, which tighten or widen to control vocal pitch. He suggests checking out videos of people altering their voice pitch and notes the importance of knowing different gases that can cause these effects, mentioning helium, sulfur hexafluoride, and xenon. A distinct musical note is heard at the very end of the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person seated in front of a computer screen, wearing a red shirt, and appears to be engaged in an educational presentation about the respiratory system. The screen displays a slide titled "Your Job" with a question asking, "How does the larynx work?" accompanied by a URL link to an informative website. The slide also lists key points related to the respiratory system, including the mouth, cleft palate, pharynx, and larynx. The bottom of the screen shows the title "The Respiratory System - Lesson 2: Mouth, Pharynx and Larynx." The person seems to be explaining or discussing the content on the slide, with a focus on the larynx's function. The background includes a room with framed pictures on the wall, and the overall atmosphere suggests a classroom or home study setting. The video maintains a consistent visual presentation throughout, with no significant changes in the scene or actions of the person.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, who begins by assigning a task, instructing the listener to research how the larynx works on a website. He maintains a neutral and informative tone, outlining the task, expressing confidence in the listener's ability, and offering assistance. The speaker then concludes the message by promising to see the listener in the next lesson.
